text: There’s a difference between the “type narrowing” behavior of `map(identity, x)` vs. `collect(x)`, right? anyone have a quick explanation of the difference and when you would use one vs. the other? In my use-case, I’m hoping to get non-abstract eltypes at the end, so preferring `Union{Int64, Float64}` instead of `Real`.

text:
hmmm, nothing looking promising yet:
```julia> a = Any[Int64(1), 3.14]
2-element Vector{Any}:
 1
 3.14

julia> map(identity, a)
2-element Vector{Real}:
 1
 3.14

julia> [y for y in a]
2-element Vector{Real}:
 1
 3.14

julia> collect(a)
2-element Vector{Any}:
 1
 3.14```

elements.text:
julia> a = Any[Int64(1), 3.14]
2-element Vector{Any}:
 1
 3.14

julia> map(identity, a)
2-element Vector{Real}:
 1
 3.14

julia> [y for y in a]
2-element Vector{Real}:
 1
 3.14

julia> collect(a)
2-element Vector{Any}:
 1
 3.14

text: I guess my scenario is pretty unique where I want concrete types or as wide a Union of concrete types as possible. For normal arrays, this runs into issues because wide Unions with lots of concrete types doesn't have very good `convert` support. So you either union _each_ concrete type with no promoting, or have to do something more slow/weird like trying to convert elements to each Union.

elements.text: I guess my scenario is pretty unique where I want concrete types or as wide a Union of concrete types as possible. For normal arrays, this runs into issues because wide Unions with lots of concrete types doesn't have very good
concrete type with no promoting, or have to do something more slow/weird like trying to convert elements to each Union.

text: This is a pervasive issue (no news there).  Has someone written up how this should be?
